instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924A: What is 820-4924A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: no liquid damage signs anywhere, not dropped. at first all rails were present, cpu becoming warm but no spin. after a bit it went worse. 5vs5 and 3.3sv5 present, but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> so no 5vs4. no corrosion sign anywhere.

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Don't get any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>4_L</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> present?
Are you using original Apple charger, 60/85W?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL> completely 0 no pulse
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> ditto

brand new original 85 watt. whole charger not just the cable

 <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.39v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.34v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 3.32v

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> present?"

Check RTC signals and <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts when you toggle <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
SRTCRST# 3,3v
INTVRMEN# 3.11v
RSMRST# 3.31v
PWRBTN# 3.42v

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.31v

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.42 on normal state 1.02v after shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> but once it went to 0.34v

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
32KHz oscillation comes out from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>?

"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.42 on normal state 1.02v after shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> but once it went to 0.34v"
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> react at the same moment?

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and s5 goes up to 3.3 for an instant when you plug in magsafe or when you short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> then back to 0.

no chanhe on s3 that remains on 0

on the rtc my scope measures the 25mhz but they are not always present. 25mhz present for a sec, then nothing then back and so, 32khz are present and well stable

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and s5 goes up to 3.3 for an instant when you plug in magsafe or when you short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> then back to 0."
So SMC so power button info to PCH and this one reacts too.
In this case, check if power supplies controlled by <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4 pulse at least; should do it...

25MHz comes out only when board starts; or tries to do it.

Check again, better with o-scope, if <SIGNAL>SLP_S3</SIGNAL> pulses at least.

threads.message:

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check if all power supplies controlled by <SIGNAL>SLP_S3</SIGNAL> pulse too; the _S0 ones.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> should pulse too.
If not, one S0 supply is bad...

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  jumps an instant to 0,4v then back to 0... ugh this is a nightmare

threads.message: Check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for pulses at pins 7 & 3.

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
pin 7 jumps to 2.66
pin 3 jumps to 3.47

only at magsafe connected or on button pressed

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
That means even CPU VCORE tries to appear and PCH knows that.
Check now SPI termination resistors and traces around SPI chip <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
You can also try new BIOS.

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
tried a new bios but nothing changed. <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> seems healthy on my reader

<RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6131</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6122</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR>

seems ok

al bios pins but gnd have 3.3 v

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
3.3V at SPI chip means PCH doesn't access it.
There are 24 resistors, not 4...
Check <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> too, resolder both chips.
Be sure no corrosion there, nor on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> area.
Do you get 24MHz oscillation at Y1915?

For some reason board turns off and oscillation disappears too.

See if pins 2, 5, 6 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> react when press power button.
Maybe need to remove J6100; sometime gets invisible corrosion under...

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check for short on any power rails; not only big coils.
Pay atention to Power FETs, at page 63; all these voltages should try to appear.

threads.message: fun. ok getting on this now. it is the last one of this batch.. hopefully i get it working. i contacted the guy who previusly atempted to fix it. he said the only thing he tried to do was injecting around 5 v into L7520 but i doubt this caused any damage
